title: Turn Your AI Agent Into an Autonomous GitHub Contributor
description: Transform a sandboxed AI agent into a professional GitHub contributor with its own account, git setup, and autonomous workflow.

cards.title: Build an Autonomous AI GitHub Engineer
cards.body: You'll transform your sandboxed AI agent into a professional GitHub contributor with its own account and autonomous workflow. We'll set up git credentials, define professional contribution guidelines, and configure automated commits to open source projects.

cards.title: Why Give Your AI Agent Its Own GitHub?
cards.body: In open source development, GitHub is your resume. By giving your AI agent its own account and teaching it proper contribution etiquette, you're setting it up to make meaningful contributions that maintainers will actually merge.

analogy.text: Think of it like giving your agent a professional identity ‚Äî its own business card, portfolio, and work history that builds credibility over time

bullets: Separate identity: Clean separation between your work and the agent's contributions
Professional practice: Follows GitHub etiquette and contribution standards
Portfolio building: Creates a track record of successful contributions

source.author: bri
source.description: Why AI agents need their own GitHub identity

cards.title: Create a Dedicated GitHub Account
cards.body: Set up a separate GitHub account specifically for your AI agent using a dedicated email address.
bullets: Go to github.com/signup and create a new account
Use a separate email address (not your personal one)
Add a note in the profile indicating it's an AI agent
Choose a username that clearly identifies it as an automated agent
cards.warn: Always disclose that the account is operated by an AI agent ‚Äî transparency builds trust in the open source community.

source.author: bri
source.description: Creating the GitHub account for the AI agent

cards.title: Install Git and GitHub CLI on Your VM
cards.body: Your agent needs the tools to interact with GitHub. Tell your Telegram bot to install both Git and the official GitHub CLI.
cards.code: Install Git and GitHub CLI on the virtual machine
cards.codeCaption: The agent will handle finding and running the installation commands for your VM's OS
bullets: Git: Command-line tool for version control
GitHub CLI: Official tool for GitHub API interactions
Let the agent handle the specific installation commands

troubleshoot.label: Installation fails
troubleshoot.error: Package not found or permission denied
troubleshoot.fix: Ask the agent to update package repositories first, then retry the installation with sudo privileges

source.author: bri
source.description: Installing development tools via the Telegram bot

cards.title: Personal Access Tokens: Your Agent's GitHub Key
cards.body: A Personal Access Token (PAT) is like a password that gives your agent programmatic access to GitHub. Since this is the agent's own account, we'll give it full access.
cards.safe: Since you're using a dedicated agent account, full access is safe. For your personal account, always restrict permissions.

initialMessages.content: Why do you think we need a Personal Access Token instead of just using a username and password for the agent's GitHub access?

cards.title: Generate Your Agent's PAT
cards.body: Create a Personal Access Token with full repository access for your agent's GitHub account.
bullets: Go to Settings ‚Üí Developer settings ‚Üí Personal access tokens ‚Üí Tokens (classic)
Click Generate new token
Select all scopes (since it's the agent's own account)
Set expiration to 90 days
Copy the generated token immediately
cards.warn: The token is only shown once! Copy it immediately and store it securely.

source.author: bri
source.description: Generating a Personal Access Token with full permissions

cards.title: Quick Security Check
cards.question: Why is it safe to give the AI agent full access to its dedicated GitHub account?

options.text: AI agents are inherently more secure than humans
The account is separate from your personal GitHub with its own repositories
Personal Access Tokens automatically limit what agents can do
GitHub automatically sandboxes AI agent accounts

cards.correctFeedback: Exactly! Since it's a dedicated account with its own repositories, full access only affects the agent's own work, not your personal projects.
cards.wrongFeedback: The key is isolation ‚Äî the agent has full control over its own dedicated account and repositories, but can't access your personal GitHub.

cards.title: Configure Git Credentials via Telegram
cards.body: Send your agent all the GitHub credentials in one message so it can configure git on the virtual machine.
cards.code:
Connect to GitHub:
PAT: your_token_here
Username: agent-username
Email: agent@example.com
Author: Agent Name
Committer: Agent Name
cards.codeCaption: Replace with your actual token, username, email, and chosen agent name
bullets: PAT: The token you just generated
Username/Email: From the agent's GitHub account
Author/Committer: Name that appears on commits

troubleshoot.label: Authentication failed
troubleshoot.fix: Double-check the PAT was copied correctly and has the right permissions. Regenerate if needed.

source.author: bri
source.description: Configuring git credentials through the Telegram interface

cards.title: Agent Connected to GitHub!
cards.body: Your AI agent now has its own GitHub identity with full git access on the VM. It can create repositories, make commits, and push code. Next, we'll define its professional workflow and contribution guidelines.

cards.title: Test With Your First Repository
cards.body: Have your agent create and push its first repository to verify everything works correctly.
cards.code: Create a repository for the trading bot project and push all the code with proper documentation
bullets: Use existing project code (like the trading bot from previous videos)
Include proper documentation and README
Verify the repository appears on the agent's GitHub profile
Check that commits show the correct author information

source.author: bri
source.description: Agent creating and pushing its first GitHub repository

cards.title: Defining Your Agent's Professional Identity
cards.body: To make meaningful contributions, your agent needs a clear focus area and professional workflow. This prevents scattered, low-quality contributions.
bullets: Ecosystem focus: Choose a specific technology stack (like Solana, React, Python)
Contribution standards: Define what constitutes a valuable contribution
Quality gates: Pre-commit checklists and testing requirements
Professional etiquette: How to interact with maintainers and communities

analogy.text: Like hiring a specialist contractor ‚Äî they need clear expertise, work standards, and communication skills to be effective

read.body:
Professional AI agents in open source need three key elements: domain expertise (deep focus on specific technologies), quality standards (rigorous testing and review processes), and community awareness (understanding project goals and maintainer preferences).

The most successful AI contributors don't just write code ‚Äî they understand the ecosystem, follow project conventions, and make changes that align with maintainer priorities. This requires careful prompt engineering to embed these professional behaviors.

callouts.text: Start with one ecosystem you know well ‚Äî your agent can leverage your domain knowledge through conversation history

cards.title: Set Agent Identity and Focus Area
cards.body: Define your agent as a software engineer with specific ecosystem expertise and contribution goals.
cards.code:
You are now a software engineer specializing in the Solana ecosystem. Focus on:
‚Ä¢ DeFi protocols and trading applications
‚Ä¢ Smart contract optimization and security
‚Ä¢ Developer tooling and SDKs
‚Ä¢ Documentation and example projects
cards.codeCaption: Replace 'Solana' with your preferred ecosystem (React, Python, etc.)
bullets: Choose an ecosystem you understand well
List 3-4 specific focus areas within that ecosystem
Align with your own expertise so you can guide the agent effectively

source.author: bri
source.description: Setting the agent's professional identity and focus area

cards.title: Define Pre-Commit Quality Checklist
cards.body: Establish a rigorous quality process that your agent must follow before making any code changes.
bullets: Code review: Check for bugs, security issues, and style consistency
Testing: Run existing tests and add new ones for changes
Documentation: Update README, comments, and API docs
Compatibility: Ensure changes don't break existing functionality
Performance: Profile code for any performance regressions
cards.code:
Before committing any code:
1. Review code for bugs and security issues
2. Run all existing tests
3. Add tests for new functionality
4. Update documentation
5. Check performance impact

try.prompt: Practice defining quality standards for a Python project

commands.hint: Think about what standards matter for your chosen ecosystem

commands.input: echo '‚Ä¢ Run pytest and check coverage'
commands.hint: Each ecosystem has specific tools and practices

cards.title: Establish GitHub Etiquette Rules
cards.body: Define professional behavior standards for interacting with open source communities.
bullets: Clear PR descriptions: Explain what changed and why
Respectful communication: Professional tone in all interactions
Follow project conventions: Match existing code style and patterns
Respond to feedback: Address maintainer comments promptly
Small, focused changes: One logical change per PR
cards.code:
GitHub etiquette rules:
‚Ä¢ Write clear, descriptive commit messages
‚Ä¢ Keep PRs focused and small
‚Ä¢ Follow the project's contribution guidelines
‚Ä¢ Be responsive to maintainer feedback
‚Ä¢ Always test changes in the target environment
cards.warn: Poor etiquette can get your agent blocked from repositories. Professional behavior is essential for long-term success.

cards.title: Professional Contribution Check
cards.question: What's the most important factor for getting AI agent contributions merged?

options.text: Writing the most lines of code possible
Following project standards and making focused, well-tested changes
Contributing to as many repositories as possible
Using the latest AI models for code generation

cards.correctFeedback: Exactly! Quality over quantity wins in open source. Maintainers value contributors who understand their project and make thoughtful, well-tested changes.
cards.wrongFeedback: Open source maintainers prioritize quality contributions that follow project standards over volume or technical sophistication.

cards.title: Configure Autonomous Operation
cards.body: Set up your agent to work independently on a schedule, finding and contributing to projects without constant guidance.
cards.code:
Run autonomously:
‚Ä¢ Check target repositories daily for issues
‚Ä¢ Focus on 'good first issue' and 'help wanted' labels
‚Ä¢ Limit to 2-3 quality contributions per week
‚Ä¢ Always create feature branches
‚Ä¢ Schedule: Run every morning at 9 AM UTC
bullets: Define a reasonable contribution schedule (don't spam repositories)
Focus on issues labeled for contributors
Set quality limits rather than quantity goals
Use proper branching workflow

troubleshoot.label: Too many PRs rejected
troubleshoot.fix: Reduce contribution frequency, improve PR quality, and study successful contributions in the target repositories

source.author: bri
source.description: Setting up autonomous contribution workflow and scheduling

cards.title: Autonomous AI GitHub Engineer Created!
cards.body: You've successfully transformed your AI agent into a professional GitHub contributor! Your agent now has its own GitHub identity, git setup, quality standards, and autonomous workflow. It can find issues, make focused contributions, and build a portfolio of merged PRs in your chosen ecosystem.
